prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity:
For band 6 observations, we set up to observe 8 lines in 3 basebands and 1 continuum in the remaining baseband. The main lines to reach our science goals are CO and 13CO (2-1), SiO (5-4), H2CO (3 transitions). C18O, 13CS are faint but included for serendipitous discoveries. The requested sensitivity is estimated using ~1/2 the rms (30 vs. 50 mJy) reached by our APEX 13CO(2-1) mosaic. Note that even though the beam sizes are different between ALMA and APEX, the distribution of gas is clumpy and most of the gas is in fact in clumps, as demonstrated in our study of 30 Dor that used both ALMA Cycle 1 and APEX data (Indebetouw et al. 2013 ApJ 774, 73). H2CO is ~1/20 13CO(2-1) and hence we only expect detections toward bright 13CO(2-1) clumps; this is sufficient for our purpose (details see Experimental Design in the Scientific/Technical Justification). SiO is to trace strong shocks so the detection depends on the physical conditions of the filaments. ALMA is sensitive so the continuum observations easily reach the level expected from our Spitzer+Herschel data.
Imaging:
The spatial scales we need are ~2" (clumps) to 30" (filaments). Thus ACA 7m observations are needed. However we DO NOT need Total Power observations since we already have single-dish APEX data.
Calibration: Default calibration is sufficient.
Bandpass Accuracy: Default accuracy is sufficient.
Scheduling constraints: None
Data Rate: The OT does not report a high data rate.

Sensitivity:
For band 3 observations, we set up to observe 7 lines in 3 basebands and 1 continuum in the remaining baseband. The main lines to reach our science goals are 13CO(1-0) and CS(2-1). C18O, HC3N, CH3OH (2 transitions), C34S are faint but included for serendipitous discoveries. The requested sensitivity is to reach similar rms as band-6 mosaics and also to search for lower-mass dense clumps traced by CS(2-1). This is estimated from our ATCA HCO+ mosaic that has reached rms ~ 50 mJy and only detected one clump at ~4-sigma level and several suggestive detections at 2-sigma level. Since CS is 1.5 times as bright as HCO+ in low-resolution data of N159S, we expect those suggestive HCO+ detections be detected at ~5-6 -sigma level for half the rms and brighter line. ALMA is sensitive so the continuum observations easily reach the level expected from our Spitzer+Herschel data.
Imaging:
The spatial scales we need are ~2" (clumps) to 30" (filaments). Thus ACA 7m observations are needed. However we DO NOT need Total Power observations since we already have single-dish APEX data.
Calibration: Default calibration is sufficient.
Bandpass Accuracy: Default accuracy is sufficient.
Scheduling constraints: None
Data Rate: The OT does not report a high data rate.
Same setup as ScienceGal N159S_band6_map1 but for the second sub-region of mapping.
Same setup as ScienceGal N159S_band3_map1 but for the second sub-region of mapping.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Massive giant molecular clouds (GMCs) appear as a natural site for massive star formation (MSF) as their abundant gas can form large clusters in which the initial mass function can be fully sampled and resulted in high-mass stars. Thus, the majority of massive GMCs should contain massive stars or massive young stellar objects. In the LMC, 3 GMCs associated with HII region N159 have similar size and mass, but exhibit very different star formation activities. Unlike its active neighboring GMCs, GMC N159S is deficient in MSF. Our APEX CO and 13CO mosaics reveal several filaments with V_LSR spanning 220--255 km/s and resolve CO peak into faint, loose clumps. To investigate if these clumps can merge into massive ones, we request ALMA band 3 and 6 observations of N159S to resolve clumps down to 0.5 pc. The observations will be used to examine the spatial distribution and kinematics of clumps, infer their physical properties, estimate realistic kinetic energy and gravitational potential, and assess if merging can take place. These results will illuminate what physical conditions start or hinder MSF and be pivotal for interpreting star formation in galaxies at all redshifts.
